sect1.title: What's New For Administrators
sect1.para: As of GNOME &gnomeversion;, the GNOME Project now includes an Administration Suite, which is a collection of tools that are aimed squarely at systems administrators. The two new tools that form the beginnings of this suite are incredibly powerful and should help administrators in both large corporate deployments and situations where machine lockdown is required.

sect2.title: Pessulus - Lockdown Editor
sect2.para: Pessulus is a lockdown editor that allows administrators to easily disable certain features of the GNOME desktop, as may be desired in corporate environments and Internet caf√©s. While lockdown features have now been available in GNOME for many years, Pessulus makes it far easier for administrators to perform these tasks.

figure.title: Using the lockdown editor to prevent system shutdown by users

sect2.para: Some of the features that can be disabled include:

listitem.para: The ability to shut down or reboot the machine
Access to specific protocols in the web browser
The ability to edit the GNOME panels

sect2.title: Sabayon - Profile Editor
sect2.para: Sabayon allows administrators to set up user profiles inside a live, interactive GNOME session. When a profile is created or edited, a nested GNOME session is started up, which the administrator can use to change GConf default and mandatory keys in their own GNOME session.

textobject.phrase: Using Sabayon to edit a user profile in an embedded window

sect2.para: Within the nested window a system administrator can create personalized profiles based on job description (e.g. receptionist, data entry clerk, programmer, human resources manager, etc.). These profiles can then be saved and deployed to various desktop machines with ease, saving the system administrator time. The profiles can also be modified and fine tuned as needed based on user feedback and since they are in a centralized location, allow for easy maintenance and deployment.
